codeBlock.code:
# Verify installation
docker --version
docker compose version

# Installation guide:
# https://docs.docker.com/engine/install/

# Create DNS A Record pointing to your server's IP
# Type: A
# Name: obsidian (or your subdomain)
# Value: YOUR_SERVER_PUBLIC_IP
# TTL: 3600

# Verify DNS propagation:
dig +short obsidian.yourdomain.com

# Check if ports are open
sudo ufw status

# Allow ports if needed:
sudo ufw allow 80/tcp
sudo ufw allow 443/tcp

# For other firewalls, ensure ports 80 and 443 are accessible from internet

# You need a valid email for Let's Encrypt SSL certificate registration
# Used for renewal notifications and account management
# Example: admin@yourdomain.com
https://github.com/leex279/obsidian-webversion

# Navigate to your desired directory
cd ~

# Clone the repository
git clone https://github.com/leex279/obsidian-webversion.git

# Or if you prefer a different location:
# git clone https://github.com/leex279/obsidian-webversion.git /opt/obsidian-remote
cd obsidian-webversion

# Build the Obsidian Remote image
docker build -t obsidian-remote:local-autorestart .

# This will take a few minutes to download and build

# Copy the production environment template
cp .env.production.example .env

# The repo includes .env.production.example with all necessary variables
# This is the correct template for production deployment with Caddy SSL

# Edit .env file with your settings
nano .env

# REQUIRED - Change these values:
DOMAIN=obsidian.yourdomain.com
CADDY_EMAIL=admin@yourdomain.com

# OPTIONAL - Adjust if needed:
PUID=1000  # Run 'id' command to get your user ID
PGID=1000  # Run 'id' command to get your group ID
TZ=America/New_York  # Your timezone

# Save and exit (Ctrl+O, Enter, Ctrl+X)

# Start the production deployment with Caddy SSL
docker compose -f docker-compose.production.yml up -d

# Note: Older Docker versions use 'docker-compose' (with hyphen):
# docker-compose -f docker-compose.production.yml up -d

# This will:
# - Start Obsidian container
# - Start Caddy reverse proxy
# - Automatically obtain Let's Encrypt SSL certificate
# - The Caddyfile is already included in the repo

# Watch Caddy logs for SSL certificate status
docker compose -f docker-compose.production.yml logs -f caddy

# Look for messages like:
# - "certificate obtained successfully"
# - "serving initial configuration"

# This usually takes 30-60 seconds
# Press Ctrl+C to exit logs when certificate is obtained

# Check service status
docker compose -f docker-compose.production.yml ps

# All services should show:
# - State: Up
# - Health: healthy (after ~40 seconds)

# If any service is unhealthy, check logs:
# docker compose -f docker-compose.production.yml logs [service-name]

# Open in your browser:
https://obsidian.yourdomain.com

# Should:
# - Load with valid SSL certificate (green lock icon)
# - Show Obsidian login/interface
# - No security warnings

# Test from command line:
curl -I https://obsidian.yourdomain.com

# Your Obsidian vaults are stored in:
./vaults/

# To use existing vaults:
# 1. Copy your vault folder to ./vaults/
# 2. Open Obsidian in browser
# 3. Select "Open folder as vault"
# 4. Choose your vault from /vaults directory

# Or create a new vault directly in Obsidian

# Add to .env file:
DOCKER_MODS=linuxserver/mods:universal-git

# Restart services:
docker compose -f docker-compose.production.yml down
docker compose -f docker-compose.production.yml up -d

# SSH keys for git will be stored in:
./config/.ssh/

# Useful for obsidian-git plugin

# Create backup script for vaults and config
# Backup locations:
# - ./vaults/ (your notes)
# - ./config/ (Obsidian settings & SSH keys)
# - ./logs/ (logs, optional)

# Example backup command:
tar -czf obsidian-backup-$(date +%Y%m%d).tar.gz vaults/ config/

# Consider setting up automated backups with cron

# Regular health check
docker compose -f docker-compose.production.yml ps

# View logs for issues
docker compose -f docker-compose.production.yml logs --tail=50

# Check disk usage
df -h
du -sh vaults/ config/

# Caddy automatically renews Let's Encrypt certificates
# Certificates are stored in Docker volume: caddy_data

# To manually trigger renewal (rarely needed):
docker exec caddy-reverse-proxy caddy reload --config /etc/caddy/Caddyfile

# Check certificate expiration:
echo | openssl s_client -servername obsidian.yourdomain.com -connect obsidian.yourdomain.com:443 2>/dev/null | openssl x509 -noout -dates

# Obsidian updates automatically within the container
# To update the base image:

# 1. Pull latest changes
git pull

# 2. Rebuild image
docker build -t obsidian-remote:local-autorestart .

# 3. Recreate containers
docker compose -f docker-compose.production.yml up -d --force-recreate

# Your vaults and config are preserved in volumes

# Documentation:
- Production Guide: docs/production-deployment.md
- Main README: README.md
- Sync Providers: docs/sync-providers.md
- Authentication: docs/authentication-setup.md

# Common issues:
- Cannot access: Check DNS, firewall, ports 80/443
- SSL errors: Check domain DNS propagation, Caddy logs
- Permission errors: Check PUID/PGID settings

# Get help:
- GitHub Issues: https://github.com/leex279/obsidian-webversion/issues

# Select an OAuth2/OIDC provider:

# Recommended for beginners:
- Supabase Cloud (free tier, easy setup)
  Guide: docs/providers/supabase-auth.md

# Other options:
- Google OAuth2 (free)
- GitHub OAuth2 (free)
- Keycloak (self-hosted)
- Authelia (self-hosted)
- Authentik (self-hosted)

# See: docs/providers/generic-oauth2.md for all providers

# For Supabase Cloud:
# 1. Create account at https://supabase.com
# 2. Create new project
# 3. Go to Authentication → URL Configuration
# 4. Add redirect URI: https://your-domain.com/oauth2/callback
# 5. Copy Project URL and API keys

# For other providers, see:
# docs/providers/generic-oauth2.md

# Full guide:
# docs/authentication-setup.md

# Generate secure cookie secret for session management
./scripts/generate-cookie-secret.sh

# Copy the output - you'll need it in the next step
# Keep this secret secure!

# Update your .env file with authentication settings:

# Add these to your existing .env:
AUTH_OIDC_ISSUER_URL=https://your-project.supabase.co/auth/v1
AUTH_CLIENT_ID=your-client-id
AUTH_CLIENT_SECRET=your-client-secret
AUTH_COOKIE_SECRET=your-generated-cookie-secret

# Optional access control:
AUTH_EMAIL_DOMAINS=*  # Or: yourdomain.com
AUTH_ALLOWED_USERS=   # Or: user1@example.com,user2@example.com

# Template available at: .env.auth.example

# Validate your authentication setup
./scripts/validate-auth-config.sh

# Should output:
# ✓ All required configuration is valid

# Fix any errors before proceeding

# Restart the production stack
# OAuth2-Proxy is now included in docker-compose.production.yml
docker compose -f docker-compose.production.yml down
docker compose -f docker-compose.production.yml up -d

# Monitor startup:
docker compose -f docker-compose.production.yml logs -f oauth2-proxy

# 1. Access your domain in browser:
https://obsidian.yourdomain.com

# 2. Should redirect to identity provider login
# 3. Login with your credentials
# 4. Should redirect back to Obsidian
# 5. Verify you can access Obsidian

# Test logout:
https://obsidian.yourdomain.com/oauth2/sign_out

# Full documentation:
# docs/authentication-setup.md

# Enable Multi-Factor Authentication in your identity provider:

# For Supabase:
# 1. Dashboard → Authentication → MFA
# 2. Enable for all users or specific users

# For Google:
# Google Account → Security → 2-Step Verification

# For GitHub:
# Settings → Password and authentication → 2FA

# This adds an extra layer of security beyond passwords
